block.p: General Casey Defends Efforts and Record in Iraq Gen. George W. Casey, the departing American commander in Iraq, defended his record against criticism from the Senate Armed Services Committee and said that Baghdad could be stabilized with far fewer additional troops than President Bush is sending.
Suicide bombers struck a market in the Iraqi town of Hilla, killing at least 60, wounding 150 and spraying body parts so far that the police were still scouring rooftops for them hours later.

From Informant to Defendant The pitfalls of the government's use of informants with questionable backgrounds are illustrated by the case of an Afghan drug lord and Taliban ally, Haji Bashir Noorzai. After the invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, officials hoped he could lead them to hidden Taliban weapons and leaders. Now he is facing prosecution in New York.

Chirac Recasts Iran Stance President Jacques Chirac, seeking to limit the diplomatic backlash over his remarks on Iran's nuclear ambitions, said that France remained committed to preventing Iran from becoming a nuclear power. A10
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, under criticism at home, said that his nation was becoming a superpower and that United Nations sanctions would not deter it from pursuing a nuclear program.

Florida to Scrap Touch-Screen Voting Gov. Charlie Crist announced plans to abandon the touch-screen voting machines that some counties installed after the 2000 presidential election, which experts say could sound the death knell for the electronic machines. A1
Bush Urges Health Care Cuts In his budget, President Bush will ask Congress to squeeze more than $70 billion from Medicare and Medicaid over the next five years. A15

Clinton Plans Record War Chest In her effort to raise $75 million in 2007 for her presidential campaign, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is asking donors to raise $1 million to qualify for the honor of being in her top echelon of supporters. A17

2 Arrested in Boston Hoax A day after a bomb scare sent Boston into a panic, two men charged with placing electronic advertisements for a cartoon around the city pleaded not guilty. Turner Broadcasting agreed to cover the costs that Boston racked up as a result.

Agency Offers New Flu Advice The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued new guidelines to states and cities in case of a flu pandemic. For the first time, officials are modeling the guidelines on the five levels of hurricanes, ranked by lethality. In a worst-case scenario, they would advise closing schools for up to three months. A14

'Failure to Appear' Cases Face Challenge in Courts The pattern of charging defendants with ''failure to appear'' in court is being challenged in Connecticut, where such cases have accounted for nearly 1 in 10 of the criminal convictions unrelated to motor vehicles over the past five years. A1

Starrett Tenants Fear Sale The sale of Starrett City, the sprawling low- and middle-income housing complex in Brooklyn, has tenants and many local politicians worried that a billion-dollar price will prompt the new owner to raise rents. B1

An N.F.L. Player's Decline Ted Johnson, who helped the New England Patriots win three of the past five Super Bowls before retiring in 2005, is among a growing number of former players and their relatives questioning whether their serious health issues are related to injuries they sustained and the treatment they received as players.

Big Oil Reports Huge Profits Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported record annual profits , but their earnings may make the industry an even bigger target for the Democratic Congress, whose leaders want large oil companies to pay higher taxes and do more to curb global warming.
Gian Carlo Menotti A composer who won two Pulitzer Prizes, he was 95. C11
